summary: Blu-ray de Os Crimes de Grindelwald nos EUA terá cena exclusiva sobre Nicolau Flamel
title: Blu-ray de Os Crimes de Grindelwald nos EUA terá cena exclusiva sobre Nicolau Flamel
description:
A loja estadounidense Barnes & Noble anunciou uma versão exclusiva do Blu-ray de Animais Fantásticos: Os Crimes de Grindelwald. A versão da loja, além de conter todos os extras e a edição estendida do filme, contará com um extra exclusivo sobre o alquimista Nicolau Flamel.

Segundo a loja, o material inédito recebe o nome de Nicolau Flamel e a Pedra Filosofal, com duração aproximada de cinco minutos. Nele, os fãs terão a oportunidade de explorar a casa do alquimista. O vídeo exclusivo ainda inclui uma entrevista exclusiva com Brontis Jodorowsky, ator que interpretou o personagem em Animais Fantásticos: Os Crimes de Grindelwald.

Leia também:

  • Animais Fantásticos: Os Crimes de Grindelwald terá versão estendida

  • Revelada lista de extras para o DVD e Blu-Ray de Os Crimes de Grindelwald

Ainda não há nenhuma informação sobre o lançamento do conteúdo exclusivo no Brasil.

A versão brasileira do DVD e Blu-ray de Animais Fantásticos: Os Crimes de Grindelwald chega às lojas em 26 de fevereiro de 2019.

The post Blu-ray de Os Crimes de Grindelwald nos EUA terá cena exclusiva sobre Nicolau Flamel appeared first on Potterish.com.

summary: Random People Coming Across Hogwarts?
body:
Random People Coming Across Hogwarts?

Are there any Fanfics of random group of people traveling around Scotland when they come across Hogwarts and they discover they’re a witch/wizard even if they are like in their 20s but they’re like the only ones to see it?

Person 1: HOLY SHIT?! Check out that sweet as castle!

Person 2: You meant that old shack with the “Danger! Do not come in” sign?

Person 1: No! I mean the fucking castle with the kids on the flying brooms!

Person 3: Okay Pal, I think it’s time we head back to town and rest up, you’re hallucinating.

Person 1: I’M NOT CRAZY! THEY’RE ARE KIDS ON FLYING BROOM BY THAT GIANT ASS STADIUM! HOW DO YOU TWO NOT SEE IT?!

Person 2:...how high are you right now?

summary: The Space Between
title: The Space Between
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2B2DnUR

by novagrey

All along it was Peter who betrayed the Potters, not Sirius. And now, Sirius is a fugitive. He & Remus have so many things to discuss, as hard as it can be do so via halfway cryptic letters, but some day perhaps the space between them will finally be closed.

Takes place in the time period between Sirius’s escape with Buckbeak & Sirius’s death in OotP.

Words: 1400, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

summary: I feel like the overlap between people who are into yarncraft and people who are massive fantasy nerds is pretty high, so here...
title: I feel like the overlap between people who are into yarncraft and people who are massive fantasy nerds is pretty high, so here is a thing:
body:
Leo, the man behind MMario Designs, has sadly passed away. His family have made all of his knitting patterns free on Ravelry, and there are some gorgeous designs up there.

Do you like the Circle of Magic series by Tamora Pierce?

Tris:

Briar:

Frostpine:

Are you a Discworld fan?

Out Of Cheese:

Banks of the Anhk:

Lady Margolotta:

How about Mercedes Lackey’s Valdemar books?

Flames of Vykaendys:

Harper Hall shawl:

Harry Potter?

Godric:

Salazar:

Tolkien?

Shire Gardens:

Oakenshield:

Smaug:

These are only a few, you should totally go and check out the literally hundreds of designs up on the Ravelry page.

summary: Omg I dont know if it helps but I entirely love your writting <3   If I remember correctly they have the cleaning left. Maybe...
question: Omg I dont know if it helps but I entirely love your writting <3   If I remember correctly they have the cleaning left. Maybe you could use the boggart with them instead of Molly.
answer:
Harry tiptoed up the stairs in the hall past the stuffed elf-heads glad to be on his own again, but as he approached the first landing he heard noises. A clattering, thuds  as if someone was running and stepping very hard on the floor.

“Hello?” Harry said. 
There was no answer. 

From below he could still hear chatter from the kitchen, he heard Ron laughing — no doubt at something Hermione said or did — and the clatter of plates against the table. But all was silent on the first floor landing.
Peaceful. 

But Harry couldn’t help it… there was a sensation that curled in his gut, like a mist that painted distant shadows on plains and fields vaguely during foggy mornings. Harry felt his body tense and began to tread carefully against the carpet, unable to explain why his nervousness. His guard. 

But when Harry heard the crack! of a spell being cast, when he heard a guttural shout exploding out as a burst of red light flashed through the slits of the drawing room’s door;

He was right. There was something was wrong.

And so he ran, his pace quickened as he climbed two steps at the time, sprinting around the corner and then flinging open the drawing room door.

“Cedric?!” he called aloud, but he could only see a figure cowering against the dark wall, his wand held out with trembling hands and a body violently trembling. In front of him, by the desk, was the hooded figure of Peter Pettigrew standing tall and sneering at Cedric — his wand out while his other hand was occupied by a bundle of cloth.

All the air seemed to vanish from Harry’s lungs; his brain turned icy cold — No it couldn’t be… How did he get into the house? Moody said no one besides those Dumbledore trusted could get in… — But Harry soon realized the discrepancies. He noticed how Peter looked exactly the same as he did that night in the graveyard, that his silver hand was still flesh and how the bundle of cloth…

Yes.
Harry watched as the white skin of a baby-sized head squirmed out, and as he took a sharp breath, an icy voice rasping the same words he had heard so many months ago;

“Kill the spare.”

A green light began to pool at the tip of Peter’s wand, and Harry whipped towards at Cedric, who only stared at Peter with wide eyes while his hand grasped his wand so tightly that his nails cut his palm.

“Ri-! R-R-Ri!”

Cedric shook so badly that he couldn’t get the spell out, couldn’t get past the cold that gripped his body, the blinding fear of the man in front, whose ugly face seemed to morph in and out of proportion. In his panic Cedric began to forget where he was, his mind running and flashing and projecting, his reality out of control and his body began seized up, the room’s walls melting down and suddenly; he was outside and suddenly he could smell decay, and suddenly and suddenly and suddenly it was the graveyard the graveyard the graveyard, the tombstones, the Death Eaters — and it was as if Cedric had never left at all, like he was still stuck in the final task, in that moment before the green light soared from across the darkness… the sweat and dirt and grime dripping, gripping and burning him, branding and trapping, his back creaking and aching with familiarity for the ground. The green light growing bigger and bigger and Harry’s screams fading further and further in meaningless echoes as Cedric prepared for his world to turn black again, and for himself to die one more t- 

“GET OUT CEDRIC!” Harry suddenly screamed and he threw himself in front of the boy, pointing his own wand forward and yelling with all his might;

“Riddikulus!”

And with that yell, Peter and Voldemort vanished from sight.

There was one moment before the Boggart would spawn again. One moment, where Cedric was released, and he could breathe and he was back in 12 Grimmauld Place’s drawing room. And where all the tightness let go and he slumped against Harry’s back.

Strong. Solid.

Cedric half-heartedly latched his arm around Harry’s waist and then with the last ounce of his strength, he lifted his head and whispered into Harry’s neck.

And while Cedric knew that Harry probably didn’t hear it, that he was probably dealing with something else that was there, something black and wispy and probably just as terrifying and dangerous as the previous horror; he couldn’t see or register it anymore, slipping away – and in one last, fleeting moment of thought, Cedric thought he could hear a chorus of angels; maybe a trumpet in the mix, ringing, ringing and following him down, as Harry forced the Boggart back into the desk drawer.

give me an au or prompt and i’ll write a short hedric fic.

Cedric shook so badly that he couldn’t get the spell out, couldn’t get past the cold that gripped his body, the blinding fear of the man in front, whose ugly face seemed to morph in and out of proportion. In his panic Cedric began to forget where he was, his mind running and flashing and projecting, his reality out of control and his body began seized up, the room’s walls melting down and suddenly; he was outside and suddenly he could smell decay, and suddenly and suddenly and suddenly it was the graveyard the graveyard the graveyard, the tombstones, the Death Eaters — and it was as if Cedric had never left at all, like he was still stuck in the final task, in that moment before the green light soared from across the darkness… the sweat and dirt and grime dripping, gripping and burning him, branding and trapping, his back creaking and aching with familiarity for the ground. The green light growing bigger and bigger and Harry’s screams fading further and further in meaningless echoes as Cedric prepared for his world to turn black again, and for himself to die one more t- 

“GET OUT CEDRIC!” Harry suddenly screamed and he threw himself in front of the boy, pointing his own wand forward and yelling with all his might;

“Riddikulus!”

And with that yell, Peter and Voldemort vanished from sight.

There was one moment before the Boggart would spawn again. One moment, where Cedric was released, and he could breathe and he was back in 12 Grimmauld Place’s drawing room. And where all the tightness let go and he slumped against Harry’s back.

Strong. Solid.

Cedric half-heartedly latched his arm around Harry’s waist and then with the last ounce of his strength, he lifted his head and whispered into Harry’s neck.

And while Cedric knew that Harry probably didn’t hear it, that he was probably dealing with something else that was there, something black and wispy and probably just as terrifying and dangerous as the previous horror; he couldn’t see or register it anymore, slipping away – and in one last, fleeting moment of thought, Cedric thought he could hear a chorus of angels; maybe a trumpet in the mix, ringing, ringing and following him down, as Harry forced the Boggart back into the desk drawer.

“Hello?” Harry said. 
There was no answer. 

From below he could still hear chatter from the kitchen, he heard Ron laughing — no doubt at something Hermione said or did — and the clatter of plates against the table. But all was silent on the first floor landing.
Peaceful. 

But Harry couldn’t help it… there was a sensation that curled in his gut, like a mist that painted distant shadows on plains and fields vaguely during foggy mornings. Harry felt his body tense and began to tread carefully against the carpet, unable to explain why his nervousness. His guard. 

But when Harry heard the crack! of a spell being cast, when he heard a guttural shout exploding out as a burst of red light flashed through the slits of the drawing room’s door;

He was right. There was something was wrong.

And so he ran, his pace quickened as he climbed two steps at the time, sprinting around the corner and then flinging open the drawing room door.

“Cedric?!” he called aloud, but he could only see a figure cowering against the dark wall, his wand held out with trembling hands and a body violently trembling. summary: Timeline of HP AU
body:
Timeline of HP AU

This is a recon/adjustment of the timeline of my HP AU. I’m not great at math but after working out some things, I think I finally have it pinned down.


Timeline of Key Events


  • Draco DOB: June 5th, 1980
  • Harry DOB: July 31st, 1980
  • They go to Hogwarts September 1st, 1991
  • Teddy Lupin DOB: April 1998
  • James Sirius Potter-Malfoy: Born October 13th 2005 (Harry & Draco would be 25 years old)
  • Aster Potter-Malfoy was born on September 1st, 2007 (Harry & Draco would be 27)
  • James goes to Hogwarts September 1st, 2017 (his birth being in October means he would have started just before his 12th b-day)
  • Aster goes to Hogwarts September 1st, 2018 (She and the school thought her birthday was on August 31st, and that’s the cut off date for birthdays for a Hogwarts Year, so she’s the youngest witch in her class)


*Current Age as of May 2019: Harry: 38, Draco 38, Teddy 21, James 13, Aster 11

blog.name: argentvive
blog.title: argentvive
blog.description: Finding alchemy clues in literature.  Mostly Game of Thrones. Some Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings, His Dark Materials, The Wizard of Oz, a little Shakespeare

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: The Prophecy of Maggy the Frog
title: The Prophecy of Maggy the Frog
body:
I finally reached the penultimate Cersei chapter in AFFC, which has the flashback to the prophecy foretold to Cersei when she was a girl of ten.  

As far as I know, there is nothing in traditional alchemy that involves a prophecy.  Prophecies, however, are a common feature of epics and hero’s journey tales, going back in western literature as far as Sophocles’ Oedipus Rex.  A prophecy may be the main driving force of the entire story, as in Shakespeare’s Macbeth. Sometimes prophecies come true, no matter how hard people try to foil them–as in Oedipus Rex.  Sometimes prophecies are misleading or incomplete:  Macbeth is assured that “no man of woman born” can kill him, but then he finds out that MacDuff was from his “mother’s womb untimely ripped.” 

Fantasy stories, which in many ways fuse alchemy and the hero’s journey, often include a prophecy.  Let’s have a look at a couple of fantasy novels that use alchemy and see if there are any insights we can glean.    

First, there’s Paul Gallico’s Manxmouse, a very simple children’s story that JK Rowling has cited as one of the influences on Harry Potter.  The prophecy in Manxmouse, called a “Doom,” says that Manxmouse will come to see Manx Cat on a specific date, and will be eaten.  Manxmouse has arrived at the stated time, so his fate appears sealed.  But Manxmouse does not simply submit; he resists.

 At this point, the missing ending of the Doom is revealed:

 But if the aforesaid Manxmouse instead of yielding and being swallowed shall take a firm stand in his defense and bravely and gallantly show that he means to fight for his life, then the Doom shall become inoperative, null and void and canceled.  Manxmouse and Manx Cat shall live in peace forever after.

In other words, the prophecy is incomplete and thus misleading.  Manxmouse’s fate is actually the opposite of what the prophecy foretold.  The lesson is:  Don’t assume that the prophecy will tell you how the story ends.  

Harry Potter also has a prophecy, a prophecy that drives the actions of Voldemort and all the people who act as alchemists (mentors) for Harry.

The one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord approaches… born to those who have thrice defied him, born as the seventh month dies… and the Dark Lord will mark him as his equal, but he will have power the Dark Lord knows not… and either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives… the one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord will be born as the seventh month dies.

Several elements of this prophecy are accurate:  Harry’s parents defied Voldemort three times. Harry was born July 31, i.e., “as the seventh month dies.” Voldemort “marked him as his equal” by unintentionally making Harry a horcrux, reflected in Harry’s lightning bolt scar.  But what about “either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives”?  Clearly that’s wrong.  Voldemort is “alive” thanks to his horcruxes in the first four books.  He undergoes the resurrection ceremony at the end of Goblet of Fire, and after that has a full corporeal form.  So he and Harry both “live” at the same time that the other “survives,”  contrary to the prophecy.  


What the prophecy does do, however, is motivate Voldemort to constantly go after Harry.  Eventually this affords Harry the opportunity to defeat and kill him.  So the prophecy IS accurate in identifying the person who has the power to defeat Voldemort; it just doesn’t say whether Harry will succeed.  It does not reveal the ending.  

So is Maggy the Frog’s prophecy for Cersei true?  Or is it misleading?  We know the beginning was true–Cersei became queen and had three children.  What about this part, about Cersei’s downfall, which hasn’t happened yet in either book or show?

Queen you shall be… until there comes another, younger and more beautiful, to cast you down and take all that you hold dear

Cersei believed this part referred to Margaery, and it motivated her to go after her daughter-in-law.  But Cersei was wrong: Margaery is dead, and Cersei is now queen in her own right (on the show).  So presumably the prophecy is still relevant.

Who could be the “younger and more beautiful” threat to Cersei?  The obvious answer is Daenerys, since power is the only thing Cersei holds dear now.  (My Braime heart wants to say it could be Brienne, but even though she’s younger than Cersei it would be hard to argue she’s “more beautiful,” and Cersei hasn’t held Jaime dear for a long time.  She has nothing but contempt for him.)

The prophecy in the book has another part, not included on the show.  Cersei explains to Taena why Tyrion frightens her:

“He is going to kill me. It was foreseen when I was ten….Tyrion is the valonqar,” she said. “Do you use that word on Myr? It’s High Valyrian; it means little brother.”

I can certainly see a scenario where Tyrion kills Cersei, but the wording of this part of the prophecy leaves lots of wiggle room for it to be someone else.  Members of religious orders are often referred to as “brothers”–perhaps a Sparrow will eliminate Cersei.  Or since Cersei was born first and Jaime is the younger brother, HE will do the deed.  Lots of possibilities.  

So is the prophecy fully true?  Will Daenerys “cast down” Cersei and will Tyrion kill her?  Or is it misleading, and the ending will be different?  Who knows, but my money is on the prophecy being misleading and the ending unpredictable.

Also curious is that the prophecy is about Cersei–and no one thinks Cersei is the main protagonist of ASOIAF.  She is not Oedipus, or Macbeth, or Manxmouse, or Harry Potter.  The prophecy certainly motivates Cersei’s behavior, but it may not be as central to the story as those other prophecies.

Harry was born July 31, i.e., “as the seventh month dies.” Voldemort “marked him as his equal” by unintentionally making Harry a horcrux, reflected in Harry’s lightning bolt scar.  But what about “either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives”?  Clearly that’s wrong.  Voldemort is “alive” thanks to his horcruxes in the first four books.  He undergoes the resurrection ceremony at the end of Goblet of Fire, and after that has a full corporeal form.  So he and Harry both “live” at the same time that the other “survives,”  contrary to the prophecy.  


What the prophecy does do, however, is motivate Voldemort to constantly go after Harry.  Eventually this affords Harry the opportunity to defeat and kill him.  So the prophecy IS accurate in identifying the person who has the power to defeat Voldemort; it just doesn’t say whether Harry will succeed.  It does not reveal the ending.  

So is Maggy the Frog’s prophecy for Cersei true?  Or is it misleading?  We know the beginning was true–Cersei became queen and had three children.  What about this part, about Cersei’s downfall, which hasn’t happened yet in either book or show?

Queen you shall be… until there comes another, younger and more beautiful, to cast you down and take all that you hold dear

Cersei believed this part referred to Margaery, and it motivated her to go after her daughter-in-law.  But Cersei was wrong: Margaery is dead, and Cersei is now queen in her own right (on the show).  So presumably the prophecy is still relevant.

Who could be the “younger and more beautiful” threat to Cersei?  The obvious answer is Daenerys, since power is the only thing Cersei holds dear now.  (My Braime heart wants to say it could be Brienne, but even though she’s younger than Cersei it would be hard to argue she’s “more beautiful,” and Cersei hasn’t held Jaime dear for a long time.  She has nothing but contempt for him.)

The prophecy in the book has another part, not included on the show.  Cersei explains to Taena why Tyrion frightens her:

“He is going to kill me. It was foreseen when I was ten….Tyrion is the valonqar,” she said. “Do you use that word on Myr? It’s High Valyrian; it means little brother.”

I can certainly see a scenario where Tyrion kills Cersei, but the wording of this part of the prophecy leaves lots of wiggle room for it to be someone else.  Members of religious orders are often referred to as “brothers”–perhaps a Sparrow will eliminate Cersei.  Or since Cersei was born first and Jaime is the younger brother, HE will do the deed.  Lots of possibilities.  

So is the prophecy fully true?  Will Daenerys “cast down” Cersei and will Tyrion kill her?  Or is it misleading, and the ending will be different?  Who knows, but my money is on the prophecy being misleading and the ending unpredictable.

Also curious is that the prophecy is about Cersei–and no one thinks Cersei is the main protagonist of ASOIAF.  She is not Oedipus, or Macbeth, or Manxmouse, or Harry Potter.  The prophecy certainly motivates Cersei’s behavior, but it may not be as central to the story as those other prophecies.
trail.content:
I finally reached the penultimate Cersei chapter in AFFC, which has the flashback to the prophecy foretold to Cersei when she was a girl of ten.  

As far as I know, there is nothing in traditional alchemy that involves a prophecy.  Prophecies, however, are a common feature of epics and hero’s journey tales, going back in western literature as far as Sophocles’ Oedipus Rex.  A prophecy may be the main driving force of the entire story, as in Shakespeare’s Macbeth. Sometimes prophecies come true, no matter how hard people try to foil them–as in Oedipus Rex.  Sometimes prophecies are misleading or incomplete:  Macbeth is assured that “no man of woman born” can kill him, but then he finds out that MacDuff was from his “mother’s womb untimely ripped.” 

Fantasy stories, which in many ways fuse alchemy and the hero’s journey, often include a prophecy.  Let’s have a look at a couple of fantasy novels that use alchemy and see if there are any insights we can glean.    

First, there’s Paul Gallico’s Manxmouse, a very simple children’s story that JK Rowling has cited as one of the influences on Harry Potter.  The prophecy in Manxmouse, called a “Doom,” says that Manxmouse will come to see Manx Cat on a specific date, and will be eaten.  Manxmouse has arrived at the stated time, so his fate appears sealed.  But Manxmouse does not simply submit; he resists.

 At this point, the missing ending of the Doom is revealed:

 But if the aforesaid Manxmouse instead of yielding and being swallowed shall take a firm stand in his defense and bravely and gallantly show that he means to fight for his life, then the Doom shall become inoperative, null and void and canceled.  Manxmouse and Manx Cat shall live in peace forever after.

In other words, the prophecy is incomplete and thus misleading.  Manxmouse’s fate is actually the opposite of what the prophecy foretold.  The lesson is:  Don’t assume that the prophecy will tell you how the story ends.  

Harry Potter also has a prophecy, a prophecy that drives the actions of Voldemort and all the people who act as alchemists (mentors) for Harry.

The one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord approaches… born to those who have thrice defied him, born as the seventh month dies… and the Dark Lord will mark him as his equal, but he will have power the Dark Lord knows not… and either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives… the one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord will be born as the seventh month dies.
